issue.title: 27 tests fail on ARM
issue.body:
I try to build `liboqs` for an unstable branch of ALT Linux. There are tests failures on 32-bit ARM arch:
```
[00:01:54] =================================== FAILURES ===================================
[00:01:54] ____________________________ test_sig[picnic_L1_FS] ____________________________
[00:01:54] [gw60] linux -- Python 3.8.6 /usr/bin/python3
[00:01:54] 
[00:01:54] sig_name = 'picnic_L1_FS'
[00:01:54] 
[00:01:54]     @helpers.filtered_test
[00:01:54]     @pytest.mark.parametrize('sig_name', helpers.available_sigs_by_name())
[00:01:54]     def test_sig(sig_name):
[00:01:54]         if not(helpers.is_sig_enabled_by_name(sig_name)): pytest.skip('Not enabled')
[00:01:54]         if sys.platform.startswith("win") and 'APPVEYOR' in os.environ:
[00:01:54]             if 'SPHINCS' in sig_name and ('192f' in sig_name or '192s' in sig_name or '256f' in sig_name or '256s' in sig_name):
[00:01:54]                 pytest.skip('Skipping SPHINCS+ 192s and 256s tests on Windows AppVeyor builds')
[00:01:54] >       helpers.run_subprocess(
[00:01:54]             [helpers.path_to_executable('test_sig'), sig_name],
[00:01:54]         )
[00:01:54] 
[00:01:54] tests/test_cmdline.py:30: 
[00:01:54] _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
[00:01:54] 
[00:01:54] command = ['./build/tests/test_sig', 'picnic_L1_FS'], working_dir = '.'
[00:01:54] env = {'G_BROKEN_FILENAMES': '1', 'HISTFILESIZE': '9999', 'HISTSIZE': '999', 'HOME': '/usr/src', ...}
[00:01:54] expected_returncode = 0, input = None, ignore_returncode = False
[00:01:54] 
[00:01:54]     def run_subprocess(command, working_dir='.', env=None, expected_returncode=0, input=None, ignore_returncode=False):
[00:01:54]         """
[00:01:54]         Helper function to run a shell command and report success/failure
[00:01:54]         depending on the exit status of the shell command.
[00:01:54]         """
[00:01:54]         env_ = os.environ.copy()
[00:01:54]         if env is not None:
[00:01:54]             env_.update(env)
[00:01:54]         env = env_
[00:01:54]     
[00:01:54]         # Note we need to capture stdout/stderr from the subprocess,
[00:01:54]         # then print it, which pytest will then capture and
[00:01:54]         # buffer appropriately
[00:01:54]         print(working_dir + " > " + " ".join(command))
[00:01:54]     
[00:01:54]         result = subprocess.run(
[00:01:54]                 command,
[00:01:54]                 input=input,
[00:01:54]                 stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
[00:01:54]                 stderr=subprocess.STDOUT,
[00:01:54]                 cwd=working_dir,
[00:01:54]                 env=env,
[00:01:54]             )
[00:01:54]     
[00:01:54]         if not(ignore_returncode) and (result.returncode != expected_returncode):
[00:01:54]             print(result.stdout.decode('utf-8'))
[00:01:54] >           assert False, "Got unexpected return code {}".format(result.returncode)
[00:01:54] E           AssertionError: Got unexpected return code -7
[00:01:54] 
[00:01:54] tests/helpers.py:41: AssertionError
```

comment.body:
Thanks! This will be fixed by #922.

In the meantime, it should be sufficient to change line 73 of src/sig/picnic/CMakeLists.txt to
```c
target_compile_definitions(picnic PRIVATE PICNIC_STATIC NO_MISALIGNED_ACCESSES
```

> @christianpaquin can I ask which code base you started off with? To me this looks like `python3 oqs-template/generate.py` has not been run with the latest `generate.yml` (including the latest rainbow and dilithium algs).

Yeah, I think my dev env was not up to date. github is confused about not recognizing my merged files. I'll probably need to re-start fresh.

issue.title: Dilithium family not enabled.
issue.body:
I brought us this issue in #282 thinking it was related but I am just going to open another one. 

None of the Dilithium family works for me and I have tried reinstalling liboqs and openssl. I have also checked generate.ylm and Dilithium looks to be enabled.
apps/openssl genpkey -algorithm dilithium2 -out dilithium2_srv.key
Warning: OQS algorithm 'Dilithium2' not enabled.
Error generating key
140391613919552:error:101280A5:elliptic curve routines:oqs_key_init:no such oqs algorithm:crypto/ec/oqs_meth.c:785:
140391613919552:error:10132040:elliptic curve routines:pkey_oqs_keygen:fatal:crypto/ec/oqs_meth.c:1401:
However Falcon works

comment.body:
Strange - this all looks ok -- except the line `cmake -GNinja -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON..`: Why do you to this? You seem to want to run everything static. When I do all of the above (except the shared liboqs build) within docker image `openquantumsafe/ci-ubuntu-focal-x86_64`, everything builds OK and this runs fine as expected:
```
root@2b0a54afbd10:~/openssl# apps/openssl genpkey -algorithm dilithium2 -out dilithium2_srv.key
root@2b0a54afbd10:~/openssl# ls -l dilithium2_srv.key 
-rw------- 1 root root 5319 Feb 23 08:33 dilithium2_srv.key
```

issue.title: ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY in Pre-built Chromium binary
issue.body:
I see a warning about a weak key: ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY, when connecting to test servers.
![pic1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717541-706bf200-752e-11eb-928e-b0239f03b32e.png)
Its happening with all signature algorithms supported by OQS-enabled Chromium build 0.4.0, except ecdsap256 and rsa3072. The secure connection symbol is missing on server page.
![pic2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717578-7e217780-752e-11eb-9a56-e9284048a266.png)
Also the "subject public key" field in certificate details is empty. 
![pic3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717601-85488580-752e-11eb-838a-899533cd9d79.png)
Why does Chromium display that field incorrectly? What could be the problem and how to solve it?

comment.body: Strange. To reproduce, can I ask how you ran the executable? Platform? As you apparently installed the cert, what does "SubjectPublicKeyAlgorithm" display? Did you try (especially) the supported algorithms as [documented in step 6 of the chromium deploy instructions](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/tree/main/chromium), e.g., `p256_kyber512`?

issue.title: 27 tests fail on ARM
issue.body:

issue.title: Missing AVX2 version of Classic McEliece
issue.body: We only pull in the vec (vectorized plain C) implementation of Classic McEliece from PQClean; we should also pull in the avx2 implementation.

comment.body:
FYI, #920 shall close this issue. One caveat: This is a "quick fix" in that it only enables import of "vec" and "avx" variants of McEliece; "sse2" and "clean" variants are explicitly suppressed: a) @bhess and @baentsch don't see much value in those variants; b) Supporting multiple optimized variants would make the "portability logic" _very_ convoluted.

Anyone disagreeing with this logic, please either comment (negatively) on #920 and/or create a "future-work" item for multi-variant, portable CPU feature support.

issue.title: Missing AVX2 version of Classic McEliece
issue.body: We only pull in the vec (vectorized plain C) implementation of Classic McEliece from PQClean; we should also pull in the avx2 implementation.

comment.body: Those choices makes sense to me, Michael: AVX2 has the highest performance of the non-portable ones, and vec has the highest performance of the portable ones.

issue.title: Enabling all signature algorithms by default.
issue.body:
In [ssl/ssl_local.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L207), there are `#define`s that assign one-hot encodings to each signature algorithm. These encodings are used in [ssl/ssl_cert_table.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_cert_table.h#L26), and are assigned to a uint32_t variable called `amask` [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L1924).

Since the encodings are one-hot, at most 32 different signature algorithms can be encoded, and since 8 bits are already used up by OpenSSL by default, at most 24 different OQS signature algorithms can be encoded and assigned to `amask` at any given instant. 

This (possibly?) prevents us from enabling all signature algorithms by default, and the question is how we should deal with this.

comment.body:
After having just enabled all algs, this is the (not entirely surprising) response by a self-respecting compiler (OSX):

```
In file included from ssl/ssl_cert.c:24:
ssl/ssl_cert_table.h:100:45: error: integer literal is too large to be represented in any integer type
    {EVP_PKEY_P384_SPHINCSHARAKA192FSIMPLE, SSL_aP384_SPHINCSHARAKA192FSIMPLE}, /* SSL_PKEY_P384_SPHINCSHARAKA192FSIMPLE */
                                            ^
ssl/ssl_local.h:355:43: note: expanded from macro 'SSL_aP384_SPHINCSHARAKA192FSIMPLE'
#define SSL_aP384_SPHINCSHARAKA192FSIMPLE 0x400000000000000000000U
```
--> We'd need to "widen" integers beyond 64 bits, it seems. Doesn't feel right. 

What'd be the rationale behind including all algs? Do we _really_ need _all_? The count of Sphincs' algs alone made me dizzy....

issue.title: Do a fresh pull from PQClean
ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY in Pre-built Chromium binary
issue.body:
I see a warning about a weak key: ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY, when connecting to test servers.
![pic1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717541-706bf200-752e-11eb-928e-b0239f03b32e.png)
Its happening with all signature algorithms supported by OQS-enabled Chromium build 0.4.0, except ecdsap256 and rsa3072. The secure connection symbol is missing on server page.
![pic2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717578-7e217780-752e-11eb-9a56-e9284048a266.png)
Also the "subject public key" field in certificate details is empty. 
![pic3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717601-85488580-752e-11eb-838a-899533cd9d79.png)
Why does Chromium display that field incorrectly? What could be the problem and how to solve it?

comment.body:
I used Chromium build from the releases page and ran the executable from the terminal with `./chrome` command. Platform Xubuntu 20.04. "Subject Public Key Algorithm" field displays following.
Algorithm combination: signature algorithm - `dilithium2`, key exchange algorithm - `p256_kyber90s512`, link - https://test.openquantumsafe.org:6299
![pic4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108895244-63c9c580-7624-11eb-86e8-c87f823c6eac.png)

"Subject public key" field is empty.
![pic5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108895255-675d4c80-7624-11eb-8b1c-160694fa2696.png)

Test pages, that uses key exchange algorithm p256_kyber512 show errors
![pic6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108895263-6a583d00-7624-11eb-9284-b938d588bcf3.png)
I think, it's happening because Chromium didn't support this algorithm. At least it's not on the list of supported algorithms.
>Therefore, only the following hybrid algorithms will work: P256_BIKE1L1CPA, P256_FRODO640AES, P256_KYBER90S512, P256_NTRU_HPS2048509, P256_LIGHTSABER, P256_SIDHP434, P256_SIKEP434.
